As it is known the FDRE Ministry of Education (MOE) distributed national harmonized curricula to universities for different undergraduate programs. Bachelor of Science in Information Technology is also among the programs that got harmonized new curriculum done by 2021 and distributed from MOE. After that, the program coordinator’s office assessed the distributed curricula before approving it and found some minor problems such as course order and course pre-requisite issues in the course breakdown. Accordingly, we found that the course breakdown order has negative impacts on our students which are listed as follows:

The Ministry of Education in FDRE provided national harmonized curricula to universities for various undergraduate programs, including the Bachelor of Science in Information Technology, which was distributed in 2021. However, the program coordinator's office discovered some minor issues in the distributed curricula, such as problems with course ordering and pre-requisites for courses in the course breakdown. These issues were found to have negative impacts on students, which are detailed below.

1.	Some of the semester load is not convenient for students due to some courses under the same semester having more loads which are difficult to be managed. 
2.	Some course pre-requisite has problems which are done by error or missing the nature of courses.
3.	The previous CBTP course code was not done according to the curriculum procedures.
So, we have tried to change some of the course orders throughout the curriculum. In addition, while doing this, we find that it is a must to change the course code also when the course breakdown order is changed according to the curriculum procedures. So, some courses’ order and their course code are changed as explained in the following table. 
Having these all issues in consideration we request the registrar’s office to approve the changed course code and course order according to the curriculum endorsed by the faculty on May 19, 2023.

1. Students are struggling to manage their workload due to some courses having a heavier load within the same semester. 
2. There are errors or missing information regarding course prerequisites. 
3. The CBTP course code was not compliant with curriculum procedures. 

To address these issues, some course orders have been changed throughout the curriculum. In doing so, some course codes must also be adjusted according to curriculum procedures. A table detailing the changes is included. We request that the Registrar's office approve the changes to the course order and code, which were endorsed by the faculty on May 19, 2023, considering all the aforementioned issues.

1. The workload of some semesters is inconvenient for students due to certain courses having a heavier load, making it difficult for students to manage.
2. There are issues with some course prerequisites, which may be due to errors or missing information about the nature of the courses.
3. The CBTP course code was previously not compliant with curriculum procedures.

To address these concerns, we have made changes to some course orders in the curriculum. However, when changing the course breakdown order in line with curriculum procedures, we realized that course codes also needed to be changed. As detailed in the table below, we have amended the order of some courses and their corresponding codes. please paraphrase this text Subject: Request for Approval of Updated Course Code 
As it is known the FDRE Ministry of Education (MOE) distributed national harmonized curricula to universities for different undergraduate programs. Bachelor of Science in Information Technology is also among the programs that got harmonized new curriculum done by 2021 and distributed from MOE. After that, the program coordinator’s office assessed the distributed curricula before approving it and found some minor problems such as course order and course pre-requisite issues in the course breakdown. Accordingly, we found that the course breakdown order has negative impacts on our students which are listed as follows:
1.	Some of the semester load is not convenient for students due to some courses under the same semester have more loads which are difficult to be managed. 
2.	Some course pre-requisite has problems which are done by error or missing the nature of courses.
3.	The previous CBTP course code was not done according to the curriculum procedures.
So, we have tried to change some of the course orders throughout the curriculum. In addition, while doing this, we find that it is a must to change the course code also when the course breakdown order is changed according to the curriculum procedures. So, some courses’ order and their course code are changed as explained in the following table. 
Having these all issues in consideration we request the registrar’s office to approve the changed course code and course order according to the curriculum endorsed by the faculty on May 19, 2023.

The following is a request for approval of an updated course code. The Ministry of Education in the FDRE provided harmonized curricula to universities for various undergraduate programs, including the Bachelor of Science in Information Technology in 2021. However, the program coordinator's office identified some minor issues in the curricula relating to course order and pre-requisites. This resulted in negative impacts on students, including the management of heavy workloads, errors in the course pre-requisites, and non-compliance with curriculum procedures for the CBTP course code. 
To address these issues, some course orders have been revised throughout the curriculum. During the process, it became apparent that the course codes required updating due to the change in course breakdown order and curriculum procedures. A table detailing the changes is included. Considering all issues, we request that the Registrar approves the revised course code and order. These changes were endorsed by the faculty on May 19, 2023, according to the curriculum.

The primers used in this study were obtained from Sangon (Shanghai). To edit the gene, we utilized a pSe-Rp vector that has a sequence cassette, which can be inserted into a particular site of interest via homology recombination, along with a mini-CRISPR array that targets the wild-type insertion site (Li et al., 2016). We designed a spacer sequence chemically and inserted it into the BspMI sites of pSe-Rp using restriction cleavage and ligation by T4 DNA ligase to target the initial insertion site. The donor DNA, comprising the inserted or mutated sequence flanked by two arm sequences derived from the chromosomal target site, was amplified from S. islandicus genomic DNA via PCR. After cleavage at the SalI and NotI sites, the vector was linearized and then ligated with the donor DNA using the In-fusion method. We subsequently transformed the resulting plasmid into S. islandicus proficient cells through electroporation.

Cells expressing Cbf5-FH were harvested and frozen in liquid nitrogen. They were then subjected to grinding using a Tissue grinder (Tissuelyser-24) at 70 Hz for ten times in buffer S (100mM MOPS pH 7.4, 300mM NaCl and 10% glycerol), supplemented with protease inhibitor tablets (Roche). Following grinding, an equal volume of lysis buffer (0.2% NP40, 100mM MOPS pH 7.4, 300mM NaCl and 10% glycerol) was added to the lysate, which was then incubated on ice for 30 min with intermittent mixing. After removal of cell debris by centrifugation at 30,000×g, the supernatant was incubated with 600 μL of anti-FLAG M2 affinity beads (Sigma) at 4°C with rotation for 1 hour. The beads were subsequently washed with buffer S until the OD280 of the wash solution dropped below 0.05. The protein was eluted twice with 900 μL of 150 μg/ml 3×FLAG peptide (Sigma). The combined eluate was bound to 50 μL of Ni-NTA beads (Promega, V8560) in buffer S. The beads were washed 3 times with buffer S containing 20 mM imidazole and eluted in 100 μL of buffer S containing 500 mM imidazole. For further purification, the IP RNPs were separated by a 5% Tris-Glycine native gel and strained by SYBR Gold (Invitrogen, S11494). The bands were excised and RNPs were extracted by crush and soak.

To prepare cells expressing Cbf5-FH for analysis, they were frozen in liquid nitrogen and then ground using a Tissue grinder (Tissuelyser-24) ten times at 70 Hz in buffer S (100mM MOPS pH 7.4, 300mM NaCl, and 10% glycerol) containing protease inhibitor tablets (Roche). After grinding, an equal volume of lysis buffer (0.2% NP40, 100mM MOPS pH 7.4, 300mM NaCl, and 10% glycerol) was added to the lysate, which was left to incubate on ice for 30 minutes with intermittent mixing. Following centrifugation at 30,000×g to remove cell debris, the supernatant was incubated with 600 μL of anti-FLAG M2 affinity beads (Sigma) at 4°C with rotation for one hour. The beads were then washed with buffer S until the OD280 of the wash solution dropped below 0.05. The protein was eluted twice with 900 μL of 150 μg/ml 3×FLAG peptide (Sigma). The combined eluate was bound to 50 μL of Ni-NTA beads (Promega, V8560) in buffer S. The beads were washed three times with buffer S containing 20 mM imidazole and eluted in 100 μL of buffer S containing 500 mM imidazole. To further purify the IP RNPs, they were separated by a 5% Tris-Glycine native gel and stained with SYBR Gold (Invitrogen, S11494). After excising the bands, the RNPs were extracted by crush and soak.

The bands were excised and RNAs were extracted from the gel slices in RNA elution buffer (300 mM sodium acetate pH 5.5, 1 mM EDTA, 0.25% SDS and 100U/mL RNasin (Promega; N2615)) overnight at 22°C with gentle rocking. Ψ-seq was conducted using the previously described and slightly modified protocol (Schwartz et al., 2014). Total RNA (15 μg in 25 μL) was mixed with 25 μL of 2× alkaline hydrolysis buffer (90 mM NaHCO3, 10 mM Na2CO3, pH 9.2) and fragmented at 95°C for 10 min. RNA was precipitated with isopropanol and dissolved in DEPC-treated water.

We used the slightly modified protocol (Schwartz et al., 2014) to conduct Ψ-seq. Initially, we mixed total RNA (15 μg in 25 μL) with 25 μL of 2× alkaline hydrolysis buffer (90 mM NaHCO3, 10 mM Na2CO3, pH 9.2) and fragmented them at 95°C for 10 minutes. Subsequently, we precipitated RNA with isopropanol and dissolved them in DEPC-treated water.

We used the slightly modified protocol (Schwartz et al., 2014) to conduct Ψ-seq. Total RNA (15 μg in 25 μL) was mixed with 25 μL of 2× alkaline hydrolysis buffer (90 mM NaHCO3, 10 mM Na2CO3, pH 9.2) and fragmented at 95°C for 10 min. RNA was precipitated with isopropanol and dissolved in DEPC-treated water. Three fifths of RNA was dissolved in BEU buffer (50 mM bicine pH 8.5, 4mM EDTA, 7 M urea) containing 0.2 M N-cyclohexyl-N’-(2-morpholinoethyl) carbodiimide methyl-p-toluenesulfonate (CMC, Sigma) and incubated at 37°C for 40 min. Two fifths of RNA was dissolved in BEU buffer without CMC. Both RNA samples were precipitated with ethanol, resuspended in Na2CO3 buffer (50 mM sodium carbonate pH 10.4, 2 mM EDTA) and incubated at 45°C for 2 h, followed by ethanol precipitation. RNA of length 80-150nt was separated by 8% polyacrylamide urea gel for library construction.
To prepare sRNAs, total RNA was separated by 8% urea polyacrylamide gel and 20 to 400 nt RNAs were extracted from gel in RNA elution buffer (300 mM sodium acetate pH 5.5, 1 mM EDTA, 0.25% SDS and 100U/mL RNasin (Promega; N2615)).

We used the modified protocol (Schwartz et al., 2014) to conduct Ψ-seq. Initially, we mixed total RNA (15 μg in 25 μL) with 25 μL of 2× alkaline hydrolysis buffer (90 mM NaHCO3, 10 mM Na2CO3, pH 9.2) and fragmented them at 95°C for 10 minutes. We then precipitated RNA with isopropanol and dissolved them in DEPC-treated water. 

For Ψ-seq, three-fifths of the RNA was dissolved in BEU buffer (50 mM bicine pH 8.5, 4mM EDTA, 7 M urea) containing 0.2 M N-cyclohexyl-N’-(2-morpholinoethyl) carbodiimide methyl-p-toluenesulfonate (CMC, Sigma) and incubated at 37°C for 40 minutes. Two-fifths of the RNA was dissolved in BEU buffer without CMC. Both RNA samples were precipitated with ethanol, resuspended in Na2CO3 buffer (50 mM sodium carbonate pH 10.4, 2 mM EDTA), and incubated at 45°C for two hours before additional ethanol precipitation. RNA of length 80-150 nt was separated by 8% polyacrylamide urea gel for library construction.

To prepare sRNAs, we separated total RNA using an 8% urea polyacrylamide gel, and then we extracted RNAs ranging from 20-400 nt in size from the gel using RNA elution buffer (300 mM sodium acetate pH 5.5, 1 mM EDTA, 0.25% SDS, and 100U/mL RNasin (Promega; N2615)).

RNA substrates were purchased from Takara. Substrates were site-specifically 32P-labeled as previously described. Briefly, the 3'-half of a substrate was 5' 32P -labeled by T4 kinase in the presence of γ-32P ATP. The 5'-half and 3'-half RNAs were annealed to a splint DNA and ligated with T4 RNA ligase 2 (NEB; M0239S). The full-length substrates were purified by 20% polyacrylamide urea gel. The reactions contained 10 pmol of H/ACA RNP and ~1 pmol of 32P-labeled substrate in 10 µL volume of reaction buffer. The reactions were performed at 65°C for 30 min. RNA was extracted with an equal volume of phenol/chloroform/isoamyl alcohol and precipitated with ethanol. RNA was dissolved in 5 µL of RNase A and S7 nuclease solution. Digested 3'-P nucleotides were resolved in thin layer chromatography as previously described and visualized by phosphorimaging (Typhoon, GE Healthcare).

The RNA substrates were purchased from Takara, and they were site-specifically labeled with 32P as per the previously described method. In brief, the 3'-half of a substrate was 5' 32P-labeled by T4 kinase in the presence of γ-32P ATP. After that, the 5'-half and 3'-half RNAs were annealed to a splint DNA and ligated with T4 RNA ligase 2 (NEB; M0239S). The full-length substrates were purified through 20% polyacrylamide urea gel. The reaction mixture comprised 10 pmol of H/ACA RNP and ~1 pmol of 32P-labeled substrate in 10 µL of reaction buffer and was performed at 65°C for 30 min. The RNA was extracted with an equal volume of phenol/chloroform/isoamyl alcohol and precipitated with ethanol. After that, the RNA was dissolved in 5 µL of RNase A and S7 nuclease solution, and the digested 3'-P nucleotides were resolved in thin-layer chromatography, as described previously, and visualized by phosphorimaging (Typhoon, GE Healthcare).

The RNA was dissolved in 5 µL of RNase A and S7 nuclease solution, and the digested 3'-P nucleotides were resolved in thin layer chromatography, and visualized by phosphorimaging (Typhoon, GE Healthcare).

The RNA was dissolved in 5 µL of RNase A and S7 nuclease solution. The resulting digested 3'-P nucleotides were then resolved using thin-layer chromatography and visualized through phosphorimaging using Typhoon (GE Healthcare).

The S. islandicus E233S (ΔpyrEF, ΔlacS) strain was used for culturing and genetic manipulation. The strain was grown at 78°C in mineral salt medium supplemented with 0.2% casamino acid, 0.2% sucrose, vitamin solution and 20 μg/mL uracil (Deng et al., 2009). To prepare competent cells, cells with OD600=0.3 were harvested by centrifugation at 20°C, washed three times with 20 mM sucrose, resuspended in 20 mM sucrose and stored at temperature of -80 °C. 
The primers used in this study were obtained from Sangon (Shanghai). For gene editing purposes, we employed a pSe-Rp vector, which includes a sequence cassette that can be inserted into a specific site of interest through homology recombination, as well as a mini-CRISPR array that targets the wild-type insertion site (Li et al., 2016). A spacer sequence designed to target the original insertion site was chemically synthesized and inserted into the BspMI sites of pSe-Rp through restriction cleavage and ligation using T4 DNA ligase. The donor DNA, which comprises the inserted or mutated sequence flanked by two arm sequences derived from the chromosomal target site, was PCR amplified from S. islandicus genomic DNA. After cleavage at the SalI and NotI sites, the vector was linearized and then ligated with the donor DNA using the In-fusion method. The resulting plasmid was transformed into S. islandicus competent cells by electroporation. Subsequently, the transformed cells were plated on uracil-deficient medium, and clones were selected by a PCR-based assay and sequencing. By this way, a 3×Flag and 6×His epitope tag was inserted into the C-terminus of chromosomal Cbf5 gene and individual genes of sR109, sR148 and sR563 were removed.

The ΔpyrEF, ΔlacS strain of S. islandicus E233S was utilized in both culturing and genetic manipulation. In a medium supplemented with 0.2% casamino acid, 0.2% sucrose, vitamin solution, and 20 μg/mL uracil, the strain was grown at a temperature of 78°C (Deng et al., 2009). Competent cells were created by harvesting cells with OD600=0.3 through centrifugation at 20°C, washing them three times with 20 mM sucrose, resuspending them in 20 mM sucrose, and storing them at -80°C.

The primers employed in this investigation were procured from Sangon (Shanghai). A pSe-Rp vector with a sequence cassette that can be incorporated into a precise area of interest through homology recombination and a mini-CRISPR array that targets the wild-type insertion site was utilized for gene editing (Li et al., 2016). A spacer sequence created to target the original insertion site was chemically synthesized and introduced into the BspMI sites of pSe-Rp via restriction cleavage and ligation with T4 DNA ligase. The donor DNA that includes the inserted or mutated sequence flanked by two arm sequences derived from the chromosomal target site was generated via PCR amplification of S. islandicus genomic DNA. After cleavage at the SalI and NotI sites, the vector was linearized and then ligated with the donor DNA via the In-fusion method. The resulting plasmid was transformed into S. islandicus competent cells through electroporation. The transformed cells were then plated on uracil-deficient medium, and clones were selected through a PCR-based assay and sequencing. As a result, a 3×Flag and 6×His epitope tag were added to the C-terminus of the chromosomal Cbf5 gene, and individual genes of sR109, sR148, and sR563 were removed.

The S. islandicus E233S (ΔpyrEF, ΔlacS) strain was used for culturing and genetic manipulation. The strain was grown at 78°C in mineral salt medium supplemented with 0.2% casamino acid, 0.2% sucrose, vitamin solution, and 20 μg/mL uracil (Deng et al., 2009). To prepare competent cells, cells with OD600=0.3 were harvested by centrifugation at 20°C, washed three times with 20 mM sucrose, resuspended in 20 mM sucrose and stored at temperature of -80 °C.

The primers used in this study were obtained from Sangon (Shanghai). For gene editing purposes, we employed a pSe-Rp vector, which includes a sequence cassette that can be inserted into a specific site of interest through homology recombination, as well as a mini-CRISPR array that targets the wild-type insertion site (Li et al., 2016). A spacer sequence designed to target the original insertion site was chemically synthesized and inserted into the BspMI sites of pSe-Rp through restriction cleavage and ligation using T4 DNA ligase. The donor DNA, which comprises the inserted or mutated sequence flanked by two arm sequences derived from the chromosomal target site, was PCR amplified from S. islandicus genomic DNA. After cleavage at the SalI and NotI sites, the vector was linearized and then ligated with the donor DNA using the In-fusion method. The resulting plasmid was transformed into S. islandicus competent cells by electroporation. Subsequently, the transformed cells were plated on uracil-deficient medium, and clones were selected by a PCR-based assay and sequencing. By this way, a 3×Flag and 6×His epitope tag was inserted into the C-terminus of chromosomal Cbf5 gene, and individual genes of sR109, sR148, and sR563 were removed. A total of 6 pseudouridine sites were introduced into tRNAs using the same gene editing strategy.

H/ACA RNP proteins from P. furiosus were purified as previously described (Li and Ye, 2006). The full-length genes of S. islandicus Cbf5, Nop10, Gar1 and L7Ae were PCR-amplified from the S. islandicus REY15A genomic DNA. The Cbf5 gene contains an intron, and its two exons were separately amplified and then joined by overlap PCR. Cbf5-His6 and Nop10 were cloned into MCS1 and MSC2 of the pETDuet-1 plasmid, respectively, and co-expressed. L7Ae, which has a His6 tag at its C-terminus, was cloned into the multiple cloning site 1 (MSC1) of the pRSFDuet-1 plasmid. Similarly, Gar1 was also cloned into the MSC1 of the pRSFDuet-1 plasmid. All plasmids were then transformed into Escherichia coli Rosetta (DE3) strains. 
Cells that co-expressed Cbf5-His6/Nop10 were harvested, and resuspended in buffer A containing 1M NaCl, 25 mM phosphate (pH 7.6) and 5% glycerol. They were lysed by sonication and heated at 65°C for 15 minutes and clarified by centrifugation. The resulting supernatant was subjected to purification using a HisTrap column that was washed with buffer A containing 20 mM imidazole and ultimately eluted using buffer A with 500 mM imidazole. After a 2-fold dilution, the proteins underwent additional purification via a Heparin column equilibrated in a buffer that contained 0.25 M NaCl and 25 mM phosphate (pH 7.6). The proteins were then finally eluted with a 0.5-1 M salt gradient at ~0.8 M NaCl.
Gar1 was lysed in buffer A and heated, as described above. After a 2-fold dilution, Gar1 was subjected to purification through a Heparin column and was eluted using a ~0.5 M NaCl salt gradient. 
Cell that expressed L7Ae-His6 were lysed in buffer C containing 1M NaCl, 25 mM phosphate (pH 7.0) and 5% glycerol. Following heat treatment and clarification, L7Ae underwent purification using a HisTrap column which was first washed with buffer C that contained 20 mM imidazole. L7Ae was then eluted with buffer M, which contained 500 mM imidazole and 20 mM MES (pH 6.0). L7Ae was subsequently loaded onto two serial HiTrap Blue HP columns in 20 mM MES (pH 6.0) and ultimately eluted in a salt gradient at around 0.5 M NaCl.

The full-length genes of S. islandicus Cbf5, Nop10, Gar1, and L7Ae were amplified by PCR from S. islandicus REY15A genomic DNA. To join the two exons of Cbf5, overlap PCR was utilized. Cbf5-His6 and Nop10 were cloned into MCS1 and MSC2 of the pETDuet-1 plasmid, respectively, and co-expressed. L7Ae, which has a His6 tag at its C-terminus, was cloned into MSC1 of the pRSFDuet-1 plasmid, while Gar1 was also cloned into MSC1 of the pRSFDuet-1 plasmid. These plasmids were then transformed into Escherichia coli Rosetta (DE3) strains.

To purify cells that co-expressed Cbf5-His6/Nop10, they were harvested, resuspended in buffer A containing 1M NaCl, 25 mM phosphate (pH 7.6), and 5% glycerol. They underwent sonication, heat treatment, and clarification by centrifugation. The resulting supernatant was purified using a HisTrap column, washed with buffer A containing 20 mM imidazole, and eluted using buffer A with 500 mM imidazole. After a 2-fold dilution, Heparin column purification was employed in a buffer containing 0.25 M NaCl and 25 mM phosphate (pH 7.6), followed by elution with a 0.5-1 M salt gradient at ~0.8 M NaCl.

Gar1 was lysed in buffer A and heated, and after a 2-fold dilution, Gar1 underwent Heparin column purification and elution using a ~0.5 M NaCl salt gradient.

Cells that expressed L7Ae-His6 were lysed in buffer C containing 1M NaCl, 25 mM phosphate (pH 7.0), and 5% glycerol, then underwent heat treatment and clarification.
